questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with a persistent cough and fever for the past month. He has a history of working in construction and has been exposed to soil and bird droppings. A bronchoalveolar lavage is performed, and microbial elements are observed under the microscope. His urine antigen test for the causative agent is positive and a histopathological image is shown as below. Which of the following structures is most likely observed?

options.label: B
options.text: Chitin and glucan in the cell wall

questions.correct_answer: B. Chitin and glucan in the cell wall
questions.explanation:
Property

Fungi

Bacteria

Cell Structure

Eukaryote

Prokaryote

Cell Wall Composition

Multilayered; chitin, mannan, and glucans

Peptidoglycan, LPS, teichoic acid

(Options A, C, and D)

Cytoplasmic Membrane

Sterols are present except in Pneumocystis carinii

Sterols are absent except in Mycoplasma

Cytoplasmic Contents

Membrane-bound organelles (e.g., mitochondria, Golgi apparatus, ER)

Membrane-bound organelles absent

Nucleus

True nucleus with nuclear membrane; paired chromosomes

No nucleus or nuclear membrane; single circular dsDNA chromosome

Diameter

5 – 10 μm; may be > 100 μm

< 2 μm

Morphology

Yeast: ovoid, round; Moulds: filamentous

Cocci, bacilli, some branching

Spores

Both asexual and sexual for reproduction

Asexual (endospores) primarily for survival

questions.text: A 34-year-old female presents with a persistent cough and fever after returning from a trip. A laboratory workup reveals a fungal infection. The fungus is dimorphic in nature. Which of the following cannot be the causative organism?
questions.explanation:
Classification

Characteristics

Examples

Yeast

Presence of buds/budding form
  • Cryptococcus
  • Saccharomyces cerevisiae

Yeast-like (Pseudohyphae)

Elongated buds, known as pseudohyphae
  • Candida
  • Malassezia
  • Trichosporon
  • Hortae

Mold/Hyphae

Aseptate (non-segmented):

Hyphae is Broad ribbon like without segments
  • Zygomycetes (e.g., Mucor)

Septate (segmented):

  • Phaeoid - Masson Fontanna silver stain+ (melanin-pigmented)
  • Hyaline hyphae
  • Phaeoid (Piedra, Alternaria, Madurella, Curvularia)
  • Hyaline (Fusarium, Acremonium, Aspergillus, Penicillium, Dermatophytes)

Dimorphic Fungi

Two morphologies:

  • Mold at 25°C
  • Yeast at 37°C
  • Blastomyces
  • Histoplasma
  • Penicillium marneffei (Talaromyces)
  • Coccidioides
  • Sporothrix

(Option A, B, and C)

questions.text: You are presented with an image of fungal spores. Which of the following is the incorrect statement regarding the image given?
questions.explanation:
Classification

Sexual Spore

Description

Examples

Zygomycetes

Zygospores

Non-septate hyphae. Asexual spores are called sporangiospores.
  • Mucor (with aerial sporangiospores)
  • Rhizopus (Rhizoid with sporangiospores above)

Ascomycetes

Ascospores

Ascospores are formed in a sac called ascus.

 
  • Penicillium
  • Aspergillus
  • Piedra hortae

Basidiomycetes

Basidiospores

Basidiospores are formed externally on the tip of a pedestal called a basidium.

 
  • Filobasidiella
  • Trichosporon species

Deuteromycetes (Fungi Imperfecti)

None

Fungi that lack a known sexual state.
  • Coccidioides

Asexual Spore

Description

Example

Arthrospores

Arise by fragmentation of the ends of hyphae

Coccidioides immitis

Chlamydospores

Rounded, thick-walled spores

Candida albicans

Sporangiospores

Formed within a sac (sporangium) on a stalk by molds

 

Rhizopus, Mucor

Conidiospores

Arise directly from a conidiophore

Aspergillus

Blastospores

Formed by the budding process

Candida albicans

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with a chronic ulcer on her leg that has been slowly expanding over several months. She has a history of gardening and often works with soil. The physician suspects a subcutaneous mycosis. Which of the following conditions is not classified in the same group as the suspected infection?
questions.explanation:
Classification

Examples

Superficial Mycosis
  • Tinea Versicolor (Malassezia species)
  • Dermatophytes (Trichophyton, Microsporum, Epidermophyton)

Subcutaneous Mycosis (Option A, B, and D)
  • Mycetoma (Madurella species)
  • Rhinosporidiosis (Rhinosporidium seeberi)
  • Chromoblastomycosis (Fonsecaea pedrosi, Phialophora, Cladophialophora)
  • Sporotrichosis (Sporothrix schenckii)

Deep Mycosis/Systemic Mycosis
  • Dimorphic fungi
    • Histoplasma
    • Penicillium marneffei
    • Coccidioides
    • Sporothrix
    • Blastomyces
  • Opportunistic infections
    • Candida
    • Cryptococcus
    • Aspergillus
    • Mucormycosis)

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient with HIV presents with symptoms of fever, headache, and neck stiffness. A lumbar puncture is performed, and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) is sent for analysis. Which stain is most appropriate for identifying specific organisms in this CSF sample?
questions.explanation:
Stain

Description
 

Mycology lab

Calcofluor White
  • Fluorochrome binds to glucans and chitin in the fungal cell wall, enhancing visualization of fungal elements.

Lactophenol Cotton Blue (LCB)
  • Stains chitin in the fungal cell wall
  • Allows visualisation after scraping or tape preparation from cultures.
 

Pathology

Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E)
  • Used primarily in pathology to visualize host cell responses to fungi
  • Does not stain most fungi, except some like Aspergillus spp. and Mucorales.

Grocott Methenamine Silver (GMS)
  • Stains fungal cell walls black, providing clear contrast for identifying fungi in tissue samples.

Periodic Acid-Schiff (PAS)
  • Stains the polysaccharide components of the fungal cell walls magenta
  • Useful for detecting fungal elements in histological samples.
 

Selected specific stains

India Ink
  • A "negative" stain outlining the polysaccharide capsule of Cryptococcus spp
  • Less sensitive than antigen detection for cryptococcal meningitis.

Mucicarmine
  • Stains the mucopolysaccharide capsule of Cryptococcus spp.; can also stain Blastomyces and Rhinosporidium.

Fontana-Masson
  • Silver stain is used to detect melanin pigment in cell walls of Cryptococcus and pheoid moulds.

questions.text: What is the primary purpose of using potassium hydroxide (KOH) preparation in clinical specimens?

options.label: A
options.text: Enhance the visibility of fungi by staining

options.label: B
options.text: Digest keratin and reveal fungal structures

questions.correct_answer: B. Digest keratin and reveal fungal structures
questions.explanation:
Method

Description

Use

Direct Microscopic Examination

KOH Preparation

Dissolves keratin in clinical specimens (e.g., skin scrapings, nail clippings) to visualise fungal elements.

Diagnosing dermatophyte infections

Calcofluor White Staining

Enhances fungal visibility by binding to chitin in cell walls, causing them to fluoresce under UV light. (Option A ruled out)

Observing fungal morphology

Gram Stain

Traditionally for bacterial identification, also useful for yeasts, which typically stain Gram-positive (purple).

Detecting certain fungi

India Ink Preparation

Negative staining method for encapsulated yeasts (e.g., Cryptococcus neoformans), revealing a clear halo around cells.

Identifying encapsulated yeasts

Methenamine Silver and PAS Staining

Histochemical techniques that stain fungi black (methenamine) or magenta (PAS) in tissue sections.

Highlighting fungi in tissues

Lactophenol Cotton Blue (LCB) Mount

Enhances contrast in teased fungal colonies for morphological observation.

Microscopic examination of fungi

Serology

Antibody Detection

Identifies antibodies produced by the host in response to fungi using methods like ELISA. (Option C ruled out)

Tracking immune response to fungal infections

Antigen Detection

Detects fungal antigens in body fluids using techniques such as latex agglutination tests.

Identifying fungal presence in the body

Skin Tests

Delayed-Type Hypersensitivity (DTH)

Assesses previous exposure to fungi through localised reactions to injected antigens.

Evaluating past fungal exposure

Newer Rapid Diagnostic Tests

Nucleic Acid Hybridisation

Uses labelled DNA probes for rapid fungal DNA detection in clinical samples.

Quick identification of fungal pathogens

Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR)

Amplifies specific fungal DNA sequences, enabling early diagnosis even with low fungal loads. (Option D ruled out)

Early detection of fungal infections

questions.text: Which of the following statements are correct? 1. Sterols are present in the Cytoplasmic Membrane of bacteria except Mycoplasma. 2. Sterols are present in Cytoplasmic Membrane of fungi except in Pneumocystis carinii. 3. Bacteria use both asexual and sexual spores for reproduction. 4. Bacterial cell wall contains Peptidoglycan, LPS and teichoic acid. 5. Fungi have no nucleus or nuclear membrane.
questions.explanation:
Property

Fungi

Bacteria

Cell Structure

Eukaryote

Prokaryote

Cell Wall Composition

Multilayered; chitin, mannan, and glucans

Peptidoglycan, LPS, teichoic acid

Cytoplasmic Membrane

Sterols present except in Pneumocystis carinii

Sterols absent except in Mycoplasma

Cytoplasmic Contents

Membrane-bound organelles (e.g., mitochondria, Golgi apparatus, ER)

Membrane-bound organelles absent

Nucleus

True nucleus with nuclear membrane; paired chromosomes

No nucleus or nuclear membrane; single circular dsDNA chromosome

Diameter

5 – 10 μm; may be > 100 μm

< 2 μm

Morphology

Yeast: ovoid, round; Moulds: filamentous

Cocci, bacilli, some branching

Spores

Both asexual and sexual for reproduction

Asexual (endospores) primarily for survival

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with dark, hard nodules along his scalp hair, which he mistakenly believes to be lice nits. Upon microscopic examination, branched hyphae and arthrospores are observed. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his condition?
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Details

Etiology

Caused by Piedraia hortae (dematiaceous fungus) (Option B).

Characteristics

Affects scalp hair; it is common in individuals with long hair and poor hygiene.

Clinical Features

Hard, black nodules that may resemble lice nits; complex structure of filamentous hyphae and spores; examined using KOH shows branched hyphae and arthrospores.

Diagnosis

Direct microscopic examination:

Branched hyphae and arthrospores

Culture:

Sabouraud dextrose agar shows dark colonies.

Treatment

Antifungal shampoos or systemic antifungals; treatment efficacy may be compromised by nodules' compact nature.

Aspect

Details

Etiology

Caused by Trichosporon species, commonly Trichosporon beigelli, Trichosporon inkin (Option A ruled out).

Characteristics

Affects facial, axillary, and pubic hair; typically asymptomatic.

Clinical Features

Whitish, loosely adherent nodules consisting of arthroconidia and blastoconidia.

Diagnosis

KOH examination and culture reveal yeast-like colonies.

Treatment

Topical antifungals such as ketoconazole shampoo.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with a chronic, painless nodule on his foot, which has progressively enlarged over the past year. Upon examination, he has draining sinuses with black grains in the exudate. Microscopic examination of the tissue reveals thick-walled grains and hyphae. Which of the following is the most likely causative agent of this condition?
questions.explanation:
Type

Causative Agents

Microscopic Features

Eumycetoma

Madurella mycetomatis, (Option C) Curvularia lunata, Scedosporium spp., Acremonium spp.

Hyphae or thick-walled grains (black/white).

Histology shows suppurative granulomas with neutrophils.

Actinomycetoma

Actinomadura madurae, Nocardia spp. (Options A & B ruled out)

Thin, branching filaments visible with Gram staining. Similar granulomas to eumycetoma but distinct morphology.

Type

Treatment Approach

Eumycetoma

Surgical excision with antifungals (itraconazole, ketoconazole). High recurrence rates.

Actinomycetoma

Prolonged antibiotic therapy (e.g., trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, dapsone) along with surgical intervention.

questions.text: Dimorphic fungi can evade the host immune system primarily through which of the following mechanisms?

options.label: B
options.text: Conversion to a yeast form in the host

questions.correct_answer: B. Conversion to a yeast form in the host

questions.text: A 50-year-old immunocompromised patient presents with cough, fever, weight loss, hepatosplenomegaly, and lymphadenopathy. She reports having recently cleaned out an old barn where she encountered large amounts of bird droppings. Upon examination, she has mild tachycardia and her lungs exhibit scattered crackles on auscultation. A chest X-ray shows patchy infiltrates and several calcified nodules. Histopathology and (LPCB) mount of colonies grown in culture are shown below. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.explanation:
Histoplasmosis

Causative Agent

Histoplasma capsulatum; thermally dimorphic fungus.

  • H. capsulatum var. capsulatum: Causes classical histoplasmosis.
  • H. capsulatum var. duboisii: Causes African histoplasmosis.

Epidemiology

Endemic to central and eastern USA; also found in Africa.

Route of transmission

Thrives in soil, decaying trees, and bird droppings.

Inhalation of fungal spores.

Clinical manifestations

Classical histoplasmosis is often asymptomatic.

Calcified lesions.

Pulmonary disease mimics tuberculosis.

Disseminated histoplasmosis can occur.

Infection of the reticuloendothelial system causes:

  • Lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, fever, and anaemia

Skin and mucous membrane: Granulomatous and ulcerative lesions.

African Histoplasmosis:

  • It primarily affects the skin, subcutaneous tissues, and bones
  • Lungs are rarely involved, and disseminated cases are infrequent

Specimens for Diagnosis

Blood, urine, bone marrow, lesions

 

Diagnosis

Microscopy:

  • Stained smears of the specimens show small intra- and extracellular yeast cells
 

Culture:

  • Blood agar and Sabouraud agar show characteristic growth
  • White, cottony, mycelial growth with large thick-walled spherical spores with tuberculate (finger-like projections)
 

Serodiagnosis:

  • Antibody titers increase in progressive disease
  • Antigen tests on urine and serum are helpful for immunocompromised individuals.

Skin Test:

  • Delayed hypersensitivity to histoplasmin confirms exposure

Treatment

Amphotericin-B for two to four weeks followed by a year of itraconazole (Option A ruled out)

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presents to the clinic with a persistent cough, shortness of breath, and chest pain for the past month. She is currently on immunosuppressive therapy for an autoimmune condition. A chest CT reveals a solitary pulmonary nodule in the right upper lobe. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Clinical features of cryptococcosis

Respiratory system
  • Cryptococcus typically enters the body via inhalation and can cause pulmonary infection/pneumonitis - primary site of infection
  • Patients may present with cough, pleuritic chest pain, and respiratory distress.
  • Imaging shows a solitary pulmonary nodule
  • Dissemination of pulmonary infection leads to involvement of other organs

Central Nervous System

Meningitis: Characterized by severe headaches, fever, altered mental status, sensory and memory loss, cranial nerve paresis and loss of vision

It is the most serious type of cryptococcal infection

Skin

Cutaneous Cryptococcosis: Causes skin lesions, particularly in immunocompromised patients.

Associated with C.neoformans var neoformans (serotype D)

Other Organs

Liver, spleen, and bones may be involved in disseminated infections

questions.text: A 55-year-old immunocompromised patient presents with fever with chills, diarrhea and new onset cardiac murmur. Candida species are isolated from her blood culture and IV fluconazole is considered for treatment. Which of the following Candida species is least likely to respond to azole therapy?
Based on the microscopic image shown below, identify the organism?
questions.explanation:
Morphology of different fungi

FUNGI

MORPHOLOGY

MICROSCOPY

Aspergillus

Acute angle dichotomous branching hyphae + septate hyphae

Mucor and Rhizopus species

(Option A and B)

Broad, aseptate hyphae branching at 90 degrees or more

Candida

(Option C)

Single-cell with or without pseudohyphae

questions.text: A 32-year-old HIV-positive male presents to the emergency department with a 2-week history of worsening shortness of breath, dry cough, and fever. He reports significant weight loss over the past month and has a CD4 count of 150 cells/mm³. HRCT Thorax shows ground-glass opacities. A bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) is performed, and a histological examination shows organisms with a characteristic appearance, as shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Pneumocystis jirovecii

Morphology
  1. Trophozoite - thin-walled, irregularly shaped, 1-5 µm in size
  2. Precyst - an intermediate stage of the sexual phase, 5-8 µm in size
  3. Cyst - thick-walled, spherical, containing up to 8 intracystic bodies and up to 8 µm in size

Risk factors
  • HIV: CD4 < 200
  • Primary immunodeficiency states
  • Transplant recipients
  • Hematological malignancies

Clinical features

transmitted by respiratory droplets and is asymptomatic in immunocompetent individuals. In immunocompromised patients, life-threatening pneumonia develops.

PCP - Pneumocystis Carinii pneumonia

  • Dyspnoea
  • Dry cough
  • Fever
  • Weight loss
  • B/L interstitial pneumonia

Diagnosis
  • GMS / Giemsa stain- mc used
  • Giemsa, toluidine blue, methenamine silver, and calcofluor white stains can demonstrate trophozoites - cyst wall is black with a methenamine silver stain.

Crushed Ping Pong ball (also called Helmet/Hat or Cup and Saucer appearance).

 

  • The β-d-glucan test has proven to be quite useful for rapid diagnosis of Pneumocystis pneumonia with a high degree of sensitivity and specificity.

Treatment
  • The cornerstone for both prevention and treatment is trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole.
 
  • Alternative therapies have been used in AIDS patients; they include pentamidine, trimethoprim-dapsone, clindamycin-primaquine, atovaquone, and trimetrexate.
